name: methyl 5-bromonicotinate
Reason: The basic unit we can compare to here is benzoic acid, which has a melting point of about 122 degrees Celsius. Methyl 5-bromonicotinate contains a benzoic acid core, but we must consider the effect of the methyl ester and the bromine substituent on this core. The ester functional group generally reduces the melting point relative to the carboxylic acid due to weaker intermolecular hydrogen bonding, by around -40 degrees Celsius. The bromine atom, being relatively heavy and having strong polarizability, usually increases the melting point due to stronger Van der Waals interactions. For a para-substituted halogen on a benzoic acid derivative, this increase can be around +15 degrees Celsius. Therefore, we predict a combined effect of -40 (ester) + 15 (bromine) on the melting point of basic benzoic acid.
